[[Image:Peter Henlein+.jpg|thumb|Monument to Henlein by Max Meißner, in Hefnersplatz, Nuremberg]] '''Peter Henlein''' (also spelled Henle or Hele) (1485 - August 1542), a locksmith and clockmaker of [[Nuremberg]], Germany, is often considered the inventor of the [[watch]].{{cite book |last=Dohrn-van Rossum |first=Gerhard |author2=Thomas Dunlap |title=History of the Hour: Clocks and Modern Temporal Orders |publisher=Univ. of Chicago Press |year=1996 |location=USA |pages=122 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xYhlNoUu-toC&pg=PA122&dq=henlein+spindler+johannes&hl=en&sa=X&ei=JSXMT-bLOKad2QX02fXZCw&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=henlein%20spindler%20johannes&f=false |isbn=0-226-15510-2}}{{cite book |last=Cipolla |first=Carlo M. |title=Clocks and Culture, 1300 to 1700 |year=2004 |publisher=W.W. Norton & Co. |isbn=0-393-32443-5 |pages=61 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YSf9MVxa2JEC&pg=PA31&dq=verge+escapement+technology}}, p.31 He was one of the first craftsmen to make small ornamental ''Taschenuhren'', portable clocks which were often worn as pendants or attached to clothing,{{cite book | last = Carlisle | first = Rodney P. | authorlink = | title = Scientific American Inventions and Discoveries | publisher = John Wiley & Sons | year = 2004 | location = USA | pages = 143 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pDbQVE3IdTcC&pg=PA143&dq=watch+clock+henlein&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fpXQT_O7EcOA2wWjrdXJDA&ved=0CGYQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=watch%20clock%20henlein&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 0471244104}} regarded as the first watches. Many sources also erroneously credit him as the inventor of the [[mainspring]].{{cite book | last=Milham | first=Willis I. | title=Time and Timekeepers | year=1946 | publisher=MacMillan | location=New York | pages = 121 | isbn=0-7808-0008-7}}{{cite book | last = Levy | first = Joel | authorlink = | title = Really Useful: The Origins of Everyday Things | publisher = Firefly Books | year = 2003 | location = | pages = 101 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=fyBb_Xh5hqIC&pg=PT62&dq=mainspring+henlein&hl=en&sa=X&ei=L8rLT9OQKsTW2gX2mfHZCw&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=mainspring%20henlein&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 155297622X}}{{cite encyclopedia | title=Clock | encyclopedia=The New Encyclopædia Britannica | volume=4 | page=747 | publisher=Univ. of Chicago | year=1974 | url=https://books.google.com/books?as_brr=0&id=Eb0qAAAAMAAJ&dq=Peter+Henlein+mainspring&q=peter+Henlein&pgis=1#search | isbn=0-85229-290-2}}{{cite book | last=Anzovin | first=Steve |author2=Podell, Janet | title=Famous First Facts: A record of first happenings, discoveries, and inventions in world history | year=2000 | publisher=H.W. Wilson | url= | isbn=0-8242-0958-3}}, p.440 ==Early life== Little is known about Henlein's life. He apparently apprenticed in his youth as a locksmith. At the time, locksmiths were among the few craftsmen with the skills and tools to enter the new field of clockmaking,{{cite book | last = Farr | first = James Richard | authorlink = | title = Artisans in Europe, 1300-1914 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 2000 | location = London | pages = 69 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QxJ3I5JgQzYC&pg=PA69&dq=locksmith+clockmaker&hl=en&sa=X&ei=18DLT5-lC-SW2gWn74TbCw&ved=0CF4Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=locksmith%20clockmaker&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 052142934X}} and Henlein also became a [[clockmaker]]. On September 7, 1504, he was involved in a brawl in which a fellow locksmith, George Glaser, was killed. He sought asylum at a local Franciscan monastery, where he stayed for four years, until 1508. In 1509 he became a master in the city's locksmith guild. ==Small wearable clocks== He became known as a maker of small portable ornamental spring-powered brass clocks, very rare and expensive, which were fashionable among the nobility of the time. These were sometimes worn as pendants or attached to clothing,Milham, 1945, p.135 and so may be considered the first watches, although at over 3 inches long they were bigger than the first true [[pocketwatch]]es which appeared about a century later, and were not able to fit in pockets. He is mentioned in the city's records as the supplier of small spring-driven clocks, which were given as gifts to important people. He was supposedly the first craftsman to build clockworks into "Bisamköpfe", small containers fashioned from precious metals for fragrances or disinfectants. For example a Nuremberg paper records that in 1524 he was paid 15 florins for a gilt musk-ball watch.{{cite book | last = Campbell | first = Gordon | authorlink = | title = The Grove Encyclopedia of Decorative Arts, Vol. 1 | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2006 | location = London | pages = 250–251 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jGsVHV098K0C&pg=PA250&dq=%22Peter+henlein%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lbfLT-2uM-Tq2QWT1vXZCw&ved=0CHAQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=%22Peter%20henlein%22&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 0195189485}} He also built a [[tower clock]] for [[Lichtenau, Bavaria|Lichtenau]] castle in 1541, and was known as a maker of scientific instruments. [[File:Nuernberger Ei offen.jpg|thumb|An early "clock-watch" ''(Taschenuhr)'', 2nd half of the 16th century.]] ==Recognition== Henlein's fame is mostly due to a passage by [[Johann Cochläus]] in the 1511 ''Cosmographia'' by Pomponius Mela:
Peter Hele, still a young man, fashions works which even the most learned mathematicians admire. He shapes many-wheeled clocks out of small bits of iron, which run and chime the hours without weights for forty hours, whether carried at the breast or in a handbag
His reputation as the inventor of the watch came after his rise to popular consciousness in the 19th century, through a novel by Karl Spindler, ''Der Nürnberger Sophokles''. This was made into [[The Immortal Heart|a 1939 film]], and his likeness appeared on a 1942 German stamp. However, although he was a notable and talented clockmaker, there were other clockmakers making small clocks at the time, and no contemporary source from his time credits him with inventing anything. The [[mainspring]] which made portable clocks possible, often attributed to him, actually appeared in the early 15th century, almost a century before his work.{{Cite book | last=Usher | first=Abbot Payson | title=A History of Mechanical Inventions | year=1988 | publisher=Courier Dover | pages = 305 | isbn=0-486-25593-X | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xuDDqqa8FlwC&pg=PA305&sig=_SRpwfz0YBAjt2aGxXhmRkZ16GQ}}{{cite book | last=White | first=Lynn Jr. | title=Medieval Technology and Social Change | publisher=Oxford Univ. Press | year=1966 | location=New York | pages=126–127 | isbn=0-19-500266-0 }} Perhaps the most that was said of him by his peers comes from Johann Neudorfer in 1547 shortly after his death:
This . . . Henlein was very nearly the first of those who invented how to put small clocks into little boxes.
==See also== *[[History of watches]] ==References== *Jürgen Abeler ''In Sachen Peter Henlein''. Wuppertaler Uhrenmuseum, Wuppertal 1980 *Maren Winter ''Der Stundensammler''. Wilhelm Heyne Verlag, München 2004 (Roman), {{ISBN|3-453-40146-8}},1510: Peter Henlein invents the pocket watch *Thomas Eser ''Die Henlein-Ausstellung im Germanischen Nationalmuseum - Rueckblick, Ausblick, neue Funde. A scholarly Essay in: Jahresschrift 2015 - Deutsche Gesellschaft fuer Chronometrie -Band 54, Seite 23-44. Published by Deutsche Gesellschaft fuer Chronometrie, Nuernberg, {{ISBN|978-3-923422-23-4}} ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{NIE Poster|Hele, Peter|Peter Henlein}} * [http://www.pomanderwatch.com Pictures of watches from Peter Henlein's time] * [http://www.peterhenlein.com Peter Henlein: Pomander Watch Anno 1505] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Henlein, Peter}} [[Category:German inventors]] [[Category:Watchmakers (people)]] [[Category:1485 births]] [[Category:1542 deaths]]

{{About|the fictional musketeer}} {{More citations needed|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox character | name = Porthos | series = [[d'Artagnan Romances]] | image = Porthos (silver) rv.gif | image_size = 228px | caption = | first = [[The Three Musketeers]] | last = [[The Vicomte of Bragelonne: Ten Years Later]] | creator = [[Alexandre Dumas, père]] | gender = Male | occupation = [[Musketeer]] | title = Baron | family = | spouse = | children = | relatives = | religion = | nationality = French }}
'''Porthos, Baron du Vallon de Bracieux de Pierrefonds''' is a [[fictional character]] in the novels ''[[The Three Musketeers]]'', ''[[Twenty Years After]]'' and ''[[The Vicomte de Bragelonne]]'' by [[Alexandre Dumas, père]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bUaYAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT160&lpg=PT160&dq=Athos+three+musketeers+analysis&source=bl&ots=r-elmbv8YG&sig=XIZ8CzRUu9QwhPkbsSP4qzXBRks&hl=en&sa=X&ei=VzDCVNTiC8yVatPIgIAJ&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAzgo#v=onepage&q=Athos%20three%20musketeers%20analysis&f=false|title=The Social Psychology of Communication|work=google.co.uk}}</ref> He and the other two [[musketeer]]s, [[Athos (fictional character)|Athos]] and [[Aramis]], are friends of the novel's protagonist, [[d'Artagnan]].
In ''The Three Musketeers'' his [[family name]] is du Vallon. In ''Twenty Years After'', having made a financially advantageous marriage, he is first known as du Vallon de Bracieux de Pierrefonds,<ref>{{cite book|last=Dumas|first=Alexandre|title=20 Years After|publisher=The World's Classics|isbn=0-19-283074-0|pages=110–125}}</ref> before he earns the title of [[Baron]].
Porthos, honest and slightly gullible, is the extrovert of the group, enjoying wine, women and song. Though he is often seen as the comic relief, he is also extremely dedicated and loyal toward his friends and fellow Musketeers. His eating abilities even impress [[Louis XIV of France|King Louis XIV]] during a banquet at [[Palace of Fontainebleau|Fontainebleau]]. As the story advances, he looks more and more like a giant, and his death is that of a [[titan (mythology)|titan]].
At the time of ''The Three Musketeers'' (ca. 1627) he apparently has few lands or other resources to draw from. He was finally able to extract sufficient funds from an elderly lawyer's somewhat younger wife (whom he was romancing and later married) to equip himself for the [[Siege of La Rochelle]].
The fictional Porthos is very loosely based on the historical [[musketeer]] [[Isaac de Porthau]].

{{no footnotes|date=January 2013}} {{Philippine name|Aspillera|Díaz|Cojuangco|ph=married}} {{Infobox person | name = Rio Díaz | image = | caption = | birth_name = Rosario Aspillera Díaz | birth_date = {{Birth date|1959|8|14}} | birth_place = [[Manila]], Philippines | death_date = {{Death date and age|2004|10|4|1959|8|14}} | death_place = [[Daly City, California|Daly City]], [[California]], U.S | resting_place = [[Manila]] [[Philippines]] | nationality = [[Philippine nationality law|Filipino]] | other_names = | occupation = Model, presenter, actress, politician | known_for = | spouse = [[Charlie Cojuangco]] }}
'''Rio Díaz-Cojuangco''' (born '''Rosario Aspillera Díaz'''; 14 August 1959 – 4 October 2004), was a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] [[beauty queen]], [[television presenter]], actress and politician. The sister of former [[Miss Universe]] [[Miss Universe 1969|1969]] [[Gloria Diaz|Gloria Díaz]], she was diagnosed with stage four [[colon cancer]] and died in the [[United States]] in 2004. She was an aunt of [[Georgina Wilson]], through another sister Aurora who is Wilson's mother.
==Biography== Born in Manila, Díaz was the youngest of twelve children born to Jaime Díaz and Teresa Aspillera. A ramp and commercial model, she was crowned [[Mutya ng Pilipinas]] in 1977 and won Fourth Runner-up in the [[Miss Asia Pageant]] that same year.
Díaz began a relationship with musician [[Hajji Alejandro]], and together they [[Filipino diaspora|emigrated]] to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], where they operated a small restaurant along [[Melrose Avenue]]. After separating from Alejandro, Díaz returned to the Philippines and resumed her career in entertainment. She co-hosted ''[[Eat Bulaga]]'' in 1991 and stayed for a couple of years before meeting Charlie Cojuangco on a [[blind date]] in 1993 and marrying him the following year. For the greater part of the 1990s, Díaz worked for television and starred in several films.
===Politics=== She was elected [[vice-mayor]] of [[Pontevedra, Negros Occidental]] in the [[Philippine general election, 1998|1998 elections]], while her husband won a seat in [[Congress of the Philippines|Congress]]. Díaz later became president of the vice-mayors' league of [[Negros Occidental]].
===Illness and death=== During a routine checkup in December 1998, her American doctors informed her of a small growth in her left abdomen. After a six-hour surgery, they found a [[malignant tumour]] in its fourth stage, and Díaz was given three months to live. She underwent another operation, and received [[chemotherapy]] for three months.
In 1999, [[Stanford]] [[oncologist]] Dr George Fisher, declared she had been cured. When the cancer cells returned in May 2000, Rio travelled back to Stanford for an eight-hour surgical procedure and another round of chemotherapy sessions. Díaz stopped the sessions in 2002, citing her body's inability to cope further, but her physicians later that year said she had no recourse but to continue treatment.
Six years after the original diagnosis, Díaz died on 4 October 2004 at [[Seton Medical Center]] in [[Daly City]], [[California]], at the age of 45.
==Filmography==
===Film=== *''Tunay na Magkaibigan, Walang Iwanan...Peksman'' (1994) *''Sam & Miguel (Your Basura, No Problema)'' (1992) as Mila *''Sísingilín Ko ng Dugo'' (1990)
===Television=== *''[[Eat Bulaga]]'' (1992-1998) *''[[Sarap TV]]'' (1999) *''[[Maalaala Mo Kaya]]'', "Pictures": The Rio Díaz-Cojuangco Story - as herself (in a part of her story; mostly played by [[Eula Valdez]]; 2003)
==External links== *[http://www.newsflash.org/2004/02/sb/sb003453.htm Rio is Safely Home]

{{Infobox Person | name = Rowena Cade | image = Rowena_Cade.png | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 2 August 1893 | birth_place = [[Spondon]], Derbyshire, England | death_date = {{d-da|26 March 1983|2 August 1893}} | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation = | title = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = [[Katharine Burdekin]] (sister) | signature = | website = | footnotes = | nationality = British }}
'''Rowena Cade''' (1893–1983) was the creator of the [[Minack Theatre]] in [[Porthcurno]], [[Cornwall]], UK.
==Life== Cade was born in [[Spondon]] near Derby on 2 August 1893.<ref name=new>[http://www.cornwall-calling.co.uk/famous-cornish-people/cade-rowena.htm Rowena Cade, Creator of the Minack Theatre], cornwall-calling, Retrieved 26 June 2017</ref> She was the older sister of [[Katharine Burdekin]] and with her two brothers they lived at [[The Homestead, Spondon|The Homestead]] in Spondon. Rowena Cade's family sold their house in Spondon and Cheltenham and moved to [[Lamorna]] in [[West Penwith]], Cornwall after the First World War.<ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cornwalls.co.uk/history/people/rowena_cade.htm|title=Rowena Cade - Creator of the Minack Theater|date=2013-01-07|work=Cornwall Guide|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en}}</ref>
[[File:Plaque to Rowena Cade - geograph.org.uk - 297855.jpg|alt= Plaque commemorating the founder and builder of the Minack Theatre|thumb|left|Plaque commemorating the founder and builder of the Minack Theatre]]
She discovered and bought the Minack headland in the 1920s for £100 and built a house.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cornwallforever.co.uk/places/minack-theatre|title=Minack Theatre history & Rowena Cade {{!}}|work=Cornwall For Ever!|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cornwall-21850687|title=In Pictures: Rowena Cade's Minack theatre|date=2013-03-24|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en-GB}}</ref> Her sister's marriage had ended in 1922 and she, and later her partner, also lived in Minack.<ref name="Burdekin1989">{{cite book|author=Katharine Burdekin|title=The End of this Day's Business|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w1qf5qa8zs0C&pg=PA163|year=1989|publisher=Feminist Press at CUNY|isbn=978-1-55861-009-5|pages=163–}}</ref>
After Cade put on a local production of ''A Midsummer Night’s Dream'' in 1929, she began searching for a suitable venue for a permanent outdoor stage.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/10245136/Carved-in-granite-the-Minack-Theatre-was-more-than-merely-a-stage-for-Miss-Cade.html|title=Carved in granite, the Minack Theatre was more than merely a stage for Miss Cade|work=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en}}</ref> The theatre is carved into the granite cliffs at Porthcurno, just a few miles from Land’s End.<ref name=":0" />
She built the theatre herself with the help of her gardner Billy Rawlings in 1931–32.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.minack.com/our-history-1/|title=Our history - Minack Theatre|work=Minack Theatre|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en-GB}}</ref> The stage took six months to build and the first performance was of Shakespeare's ''The Tempest'' in summer 1932. Without any formal lighting, the performance used batteries and car headlights to light the stage.<ref name=":1" />
In 1976, Cade gave the theatre to a charitable trust.<ref name=":1" /> She died on 26 March 1983.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.engineering-timelines.com/scripts/engineeringItem.asp?id=1055|title=Engineering Timelines - Minack Theatre|website=www.engineering-timelines.com|access-date=2017-06-26}}</ref> The Cade family continued to be involved in the theatre – the general manager in 2015 was married to Rowena's great niece.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Desforges|first=Kate Elizabeth|date=Jan 2015|title=Burdekin’s Utopian Visions: A Study of Four Interwar Texts|url=https://hydra.hull.ac.uk/assets/hull:14090a/content|journal=|volume=PhD Thesis|pages=|via=University of Hull}}</ref> The theatre is now managed by Philip Jackson and has featured in a number of BBC programmes about the South West of Britain.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p04fl6zs|title=Minack Theatre - drama by the sea, Coastal Path - BBC One|website=BBC|access-date=2017-06-26}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Countryfile|title=Minack Theatre and Rowena Cade (Cornwall) - BBC - 24th April 2016|date=2016-04-25|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mrs6s3zBeD4|accessdate=2017-06-26}}</ref>

:::::''For the Sheldon Mayer comic-book feature, see [[Scribbly the Boy Cartoonist]]''
'''''Scribbly''''' was a Dutch comic strip, created by Jan-Paul Arends. It ran daily in the Dutch edition of the ''[[Metro International|Metro]]'' free newspaper from 1999 to 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/artists/a/arends_jp.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-01-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120506094241/http://lambiek.net/artists/a/arends_jp.htm |archivedate=2012-05-06 |df= }}</ref> Seven albums have been published containing the daily strips. The comic is known for its weird cast, and its tendency for parodying well-known films, books and famous people.
==Cast== * '''Scribbly''' is the eponymous protagonist. He is a [[schizophrenic]] and lives in an institute for people who are mentally disturbed. * '''Psychotron''' is Scribbly's super-hero [[alter ego]], in a few strips where he deludedly wears a red cape, which allows him to think he can fly. * '''Frits''' is Scribbly's voice-inside-his-head. * '''Quibus''' is an animated sheet of paper who is usually Scribbly's friend. * '''Doctor Psilo''' leads the House for the Mentally Disturbed. * '''Zark''' is an extraterrestrial alien who looks like a giant pickle with an antenna. He can use the antenna for radio reception, remote control, as well as hearing Frits. He hails from planet Zortian II. * '''Kraz''' is Zark's brother. He lives on the same planet where Zark used to live. * '''Waverider''' is Zark's [[super-hero]] alter ego, who has no known powers. * '''Doe-ran''' is a haunting spirit, in the shape of a floating mask, that was initially summoned by Quibus to torment Scribbly. He is a powerful magician. * '''Draakje''' is a little dragon that doesn't talk and has a tendency of breathing fire at inconvenient moments. He barks just like a dog. * '''Olav''' is a huge man who is a [[porter (carrier)|porter]] at the House. He shouts a lot. * '''V-252''' is a friendly robot from outer space with a television on his belly. He is married to another robot, and they have a toaster for a child. * '''H-Nibal''' is a huge killer robot from outer space, who was eventually defeated by D-2120. * '''Mildred''' is a nurse at the House, who keeps an eye on the patients using Meneer Pollepel. * '''Pollepel''' is a ladle with a drawn-on angry face. When used, he scares the patients. * '''Eddy''' is one of the newer patients in the House, and is a naughty baby duck. He likes wine, and drives around the house in a pink toy [[Cadillac]]. * '''Geestenclub''' are four ghosts who incidentally appear in the comics. * '''Flumpy''' is a huge bee, who is the [[mascot]] of the brand of cereal eaten in the House. * '''Giovanni''' is a shrimp, who is sometimes being drawn by Zark in an attempt to create a comic book. Giovanni lives in Garnaalsmeer. * '''Zen''' is a robot who thinks for himself, created by V-252.
==Albums== # "Ik hoop dat die ene goeie erin staat" (I hope that good one is in here) # "Ik snap ze nooit" (I never get them) # "Doe maar iets creatiefs" (Make it something creative) # "Daar moet je een stripje over maken" (You should make a comic about that) # "De verzonken stad van Zahn-Luac" (The lost city of Zahn-Luac) # "Een opsteker van jewelste" (A big stroke of luck) # "Meer wafels, minder misdaad" (More waffles, less crime) # "Het is maar een droom, jongen" (It's just a dream, son) # "Absurdor"

{{Infobox NFL player | name = Steve Smith | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | number = 35 | position = [[Fullback (American football)|Fullback]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|8|30}} | birth_place = [[Washington, D.C.]] | death_date = | death_place = | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 1 | weight_lbs = 242 | high_school = [[DeMatha Catholic High School|DeMatha Catholic]]
([[Hyattsville, Maryland]]) | college = [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]] | draftyear = 1987 | draftround = 3 | draftpick = 81 | pastteams = * [[Oakland Raiders|Los Angeles Raiders]] (1987–1993) * [[Seattle Seahawks]] (1994–1995) | nflnew = stevesmith/2503052 | pfr = SmitSt00 }} '''Steven Anthony Smith''' (born August 30, 1964) is a former professional [[American football]] [[fullback (gridiron football)|fullback]], playing 9 seasons in the [[National Football League]] with the [[Oakland Raiders]] and [[Seattle Seahawks]]. He was a [[Captain (sports)|team captain]] on [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]]'s [[Penn State Nittany Lions football under Joe Paterno (as an Independent)#1986 season|1986 National Championship]] team. Smith was a third-round draft choice of the Raiders in the [[1987 NFL Draft]]. Converted to [[Fullback (American football)|fullback]], Smith blocked for Raiders star running backs [[Bo Jackson]] and [[Marcus Allen]]. He then spent 2 seasons with Seattle until a back injury ended his career.{{cite web| url = http://www.napavalleyregister.com/articles/2006/12/29/sports/college_and_pro/doc45952bd9108ce651032684.txt | title = Former Raider fullback Smith battles illness | last = Armas | first = Genaro C. | publisher = The Associated Press | date = 2006-12-29 | accessdate = 2008-11-02}} Although primarily a blocker, he finished his career with 1627 rushing yards and 13 receiving touchdowns. In 1995, Smith won the inaugural [[Madden Bowl#The Madden Bowl|Madden Bowl]], a tournament during [[Super Bowl]] weekend in which current and former NFL players compete at the [[Madden NFL]] [[video game]]. ==After football== Smith married former [[Oakland Raiderettes|Raiderette]], Chie Aguilar-Hiroto from Cypress, CA in December 1989.{{cite web| url = http://www.raiderdrive.com/commitment_to_acceptance1.htm | title = Oakland Raider Steve Smith: Commitment to Acceptance | last = Turse | first = Paul | publisher = raiderdrive.com | accessdate = 2008-11-02}} The couple have two children, Dante (July 1990) and Jazmin (Sept 1991) and live in [[Richardson, Texas]]. Smith has been afflicted with [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|Lou Gehrig's disease]] since July 2002. He cannot speak because of a [[ventilator]] and receives his food through a [[feeding tube]]. He communicates via a state of the art computer system paid for by The Steve Gleason Foundation, reported his wife. Smith was the focus of an August 17, 2010, episode of [[HBO]]'s ''[[Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel]]'' exploring how toxic proteins that form after brain trauma may cause Lou Gehrig's disease.{{cite web | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/2010/08/17/2010-08-17_head_traumaals_link_found_report.html#ixzz0wsaZ3qIl | title = Boston University study by Ann McKee finds link between concussions and Lou Gehrig's disease | first = Michael | last = O'Keeffe | publisher = ''[[Daily News (New York)|NY Daily News]]'' | date = 2010-08-17}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} *[http://www.raiderdrive.com/commitment_to_acceptance1.htm "Commitment to Acceptance"], Paul Turse, raiderdrive.com *[http://209.157.64.200/focus/f-news/949174/posts Former Raider With ALS Wants To Help Others], ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'', July 19, 2003 *[http://www.napavalleyregister.com/articles/2006/12/29/sports/college_and_pro/doc45952bd9108ce651032684.txt Former Raider fullback Smith battles illness], Genaro C. Armas, The Associated Press, December 29, 2006 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090418192218/http://www.canlyme.com/NFLALS2004.html "Show of strength: Doctors told Steve Smith he was dying of ALS. He is now convinced that is not true"], Frank Bodani, ''[[York Daily Record]]'', July 11, 2004. *[http://www.ydr.com/ci_15492485 "Former PSU fullback Steve Smith still has strength to fight"], Frank Bodani, ''[[York Daily Record]]'', July 15, 2010. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lIsa6m_ak8o&feature=related “Former Oakland Raider, Steve Smith, and his fight against ALS”], ESPN Video. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F6FJMcUO4zw&feature=related “Steve Smith, former Penn State and Raider Football Player, has ALS”], ''[[Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel]]'', [[HBO]], August 17, 2010. {{1986 Penn State Nittany Lions football navbox}} {{Raiders1987DraftPicks}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Smith, Steve}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American football running backs]] [[Category:DeMatha Catholic High School alumni]] [[Category:Los Angeles Raiders players]] [[Category:Penn State Nittany Lions football players]] [[Category:Players of American football from Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:People with motor neuron disease]] [[Category:Players of American football from Maryland]] [[Category:Seattle Seahawks players]]

{{Use British English|date=December 2016}} '''Thomas Judson Brooks''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|MBE|JP}} (7 July 1880 – 15 February 1958) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] coal miner and politician who became a [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] [[Member of Parliament]]. A [[spiritualism|spiritualist]], his main achievement was to lead the successful campaign to repeal the [[Witchcraft Act 1735]].
==Working life== Brooks was born on Eastfield Farm at [[Thurgoland]] near [[Barnsley]], [[Yorkshire]], where his father was a farmer. He attended Thurgoland Church School, and on leaving instead of following his father into farming, he became a coal miner at [[Glass Houghton]]. Active in the Yorkshire Mine Workers' Association, he became Secretary of his branch of the Union in 1911. He was elected as a [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] candidate to [[Castleford]] [[Urban District Council]] in 1914.
==Local politics== In 1924 Brooks was appointed Chairman of Wakefield and Pontefract War Pension Committee and made a [[Justice of the Peace]] for the [[West Riding of Yorkshire]]. In the next year he was elected to the West Riding County Council, on which he remained until 1942 and was elected as a County [[Alderman]] in 1940. He was also Chairman of Trustees for Castleford, Normanton and District Hospital. In 1931 he was awarded [[Order of the British Empire|Membership of the Order of the British Empire]] for services to the local community.
==Election to Parliament== When the Labour MP [[William Lunn]] died in May 1942, Brooks won the endorsement of the Yorkshire Miners' Association, and at the [[Rothwell by-election, 1942|Rothwell by-election in August]] he was elected unopposed as Labour [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Rothwell (UK Parliament constituency)|Rothwell]]. After the end of the war Brooks was appointed to a Committee advising the Speaker on the rebuilding of the Chamber of the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]], which had been destroyed by German bombs in 1941. He was a firm opponent of [[capital punishment in the United Kingdom|capital punishment]].
==Spiritualism== Brooks' most pressing issue was that of [[Spiritualism]], as he was an ardent spiritualist himself. He led delegations from the [[Spiritualists' National Union]] to the Home Secretary over what spiritualists believed was heavy-handed policing, and in 1943 obtained a concession that action would only be taken in the most extreme cases of misrepresentation. However, after the prosecution of medium [[Helen Duncan]] in 1944, the Spiritualists decided to campaign for a change in the law.
With [[Private Member's Bill]]s having been suspended during the [[Second World War]] and for some years afterwards, it was not until 1950 that an opportunity emerged. Brooks' friend [[Walter Monslow, Baron Monslow|Walter Monslow]] won a spot in the annual ballot for Bills, and Brooks persuaded him to introduce a Bill to repeal the [[Witchcraft Act 1735]] and replace it with an Act criminalising deliberate deception. With Brooks' guidance, the [[Fraudulent Mediums Act 1951]] was passed unanimously.
Brooks retired from Parliament at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1951|1951 general election]].
==References== *Obituary, ''[[The Times]]'', 17 February 1958 *''Who Was Who'', A & C Black *Malcolm Gaskill, "Hellish Nell: Last of Britain's Witches" (Fourth Estate, 2001)

{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=August 2008}} {{expert needed|date=April 2015}} }} '''Tim Newsham''' is a [[computer security]] professional. He has been contributing to the security community for more than a decade. He has performed research while working at security companies including [[@stake]], Guardent, ISS, and [[Network Associates]] (originally Secure Networks).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenewsh.com/~newsham/ |title=Tim Newsham's Personal Webpage |accessdate=2011-08-26}}</ref>
==Contributions== Newsham is best known for co-authoring the paper ''Insertion, Evasion and Denial of Service: Eluding Network Intrusion Detection''<ref>Newsham, Timothy; and Ptacek, Thomas (1998-01). Insertion, Evasion and Denial of Service: Eluding Network Intrusion Detection. January 1998. Retrieved from http://insecure.org/stf/secnet_ids/secnet_ids.html.</ref> with Thomas Ptacek, a paper that broke every Network Intrusion Detection product on the market and has been cited by more than 150 academic works on Network Intrusion Detection since.<ref name="insertion-evasion-dos">{{cite web |url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/showciting?doi=10.1.1.42.5765 |title=Citation Query Insertion, Evasion and Denial of Service |work=CiteSeerX |accessdate=2011-08-29 }}</ref>
He has published other prominent white papers: * ''The Problem With Random Increments''<ref>The Problem With Random Increments. Retrieved from http://www.thenewsh.com/~newsham/random-increments.pdf.</ref> * ''Format String Attacks''<ref>Format String Attacks. Retrieved from http://seclists.org/bugtraq/2000/Sep/0214.html.</ref> * ''Cracking WEP Keys: Applying Known Techniques to WEP Keys''<ref>Cracking WEP Keys: Applying Known Techniques to WEP Keys. Retrieved from http://www.lava.net/~newsham/wlan/WEP_password_cracker.pdf.</ref>
In addition to his research, Newsham is also known for his pioneering work on security products, including:{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} * Internet Security Scanner * Ballista (Cybercop) Scanner * The software{{clarify|date=April 2015}} that would later drive [[Veracode]]
== WEP Security == Newsham partially discovered the '''Newsham 21-bit''' WEP attack. The Newsham 21-bit attack is a method used primarily by [[KisMAC]] to brute force WEP keys. It is effective on routers such as [[Linksys]], [[Netgear]], [[Belkin]], and [[D-Link]] but does not affect [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] or [[3Com]], as they use their own [[algorithms]] for generating [[Wired Equivalent Privacy|WEP]] keys. Using this method allows for the WEP key to be retrieved in less than a minute. When the WEP keys are generated, they use a text based key that is generated using a 21-bit algorithm instead of the more secure 40-bit encryption algorithm, but the router presents the key to the user as a 40-bit key. This method is 2^19 times faster to brute force than a 40-bit key would be, allowing modern processors to break the encryption rapidly.<ref>http://kismac-ng.org/ kismac-ng.org</ref><ref>http://projects.cerias.purdue.edu/secprog/class3/7.Wireless.pdf</ref>
In 2008, Newsham was awarded a Lifetime Achievement [[Pwnie award]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pwnies.com/archive/2008/winners/#lifetime |title=2008 Pwnie Awards |accessdate=2011-08-29}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} '''William Brownlow''' [[Privy Council of Ireland|PC (I)]] (10 April 1726 – 28 October 1794) was an [[Anglo-Irish]] politician. He was the only son of [[William Brownlow (1683-1739)|William Brownlow]] MP and Lady Elizabeth Hamilton, daughter of [[James Hamilton, 6th Earl of Abercorn]] and Elizabeth Reading. Brownlow was first elected to the [[Irish House of Commons]] as the [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Armagh County (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Armagh County]] in 1753, holding the seat until 1794. He was also returned for the [[Strabane (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Strabane]] constituency in 1768, but was replaced in 1769.E. M. Johnston-Liik, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jitdluWSybIC&pg=PA92&lpg=PA92&dq=Alexander+Gradon+naas+mp&source=bl&ots=OWYBWe6i_R&sig=1IBtQjrwGSvhBFPYDM5_MrQv4Zg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwix8ZzOoYnLAhVL2BoKHSlICEcQ6AEIMjAD#v=snippet&q=brownlow&f=false ''MPs in Dublin: Companion to History of the Irish Parliament, 1692-1800''] (Ulster Historical Foundation, 2006), p.74 (Retrieved 26 February 2016). He married firstly Judith Letitia Meredith, daughter of the Reverend Charles Meredith, [[Dean of Limerick and Ardfert|Dean of Ardfert]], and had at least four children, including Charles, his heir. One of their daughters, Frances Letitia, married [[John Vesey, 2nd Viscount de Vesci]]. He married secondly Catherine Hall, daughter of Roger Hall of Mount Hall, [[County Down]], by whom he had ten more children, including Elizabeth, who married [[John Bligh, 4th Earl of Darnley]]. Charles, his eldest surviving son and heir, was the father of [[Charles Brownlow, 1st Baron Lurgan]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|ie}} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Armagh County (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Armagh County]] | with = [[William Richardson (1710–1758)|William Richardson]] (1753–1758) | with2 = [[Francis Caulfeild]] (1758–1761) | with3 = [[Archibald Acheson, 1st Viscount Gosford|Sir Archibald Acheson, Bt.]] (1761–1776) | with4 = [[Thomas Dawson (politician)|Thomas Dawson]] (1776–1783) | with5 = [[William Richardson (1749–1822)|William Richardson]] (1783–1794) | years = 1753–1794 | before = [[William Richardson (1710–1758)|William Richardson]]

{{short description|19th and 20th-century founder of the Ghost Dance movement}} {{About|the Northern Paiute religious leader|the [[Redbone (band)|Redbone]] album and eponymous single|Wovoka (album)}} {{Infobox American Indian chief | name = Wovoka | image = Wovoka Paiute Shaman.jpg | image_size = | caption = Wovoka – [[Northern Paiute|Paiute]] spiritual leader and creator of the [[Ghost Dance]] | tribe = [[Northern Paiute]] | lead = | birth_date = c. 1856 | birth_place = [[Smith Valley, Nevada]] | death_date = September 29, 1932<ref>go.grolier.com</ref> | death_place = [[Yerington, Nevada]] | predecessor = | successor = | native_name = | nicknames = '''Jack Wilson''' | known_for = Spiritual leader and creator of the [[Ghost Dance]] | death_cause = | resting_place = [[Schurz, Nevada]] | rp_coordinates = | religion = | party = | education = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | signature = | footnotes = }}
'''Wovoka''' (c. 1856 - September 20, 1932),<ref name="Trafzer1986">{{cite book|author=Clifford E. Trafzer|title=American Indian prophets: religious leaders and revitalization movements|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CVNwAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=23 July 2013|date=April 1986|publisher=Sierra Oaks Pub. Co.|page=108|quote=Wovoka, the great Ghost Dance Prophet, died on September 20, 1932 and was buried in the heart of the Paiute country. Joseph McDonald of the Reno ... his body was taken to the Paiute cemetery at Shurtz. As family and friends shoveled dirt ...}}</ref> also known as '''Jack Wilson''', was the [[Northern Paiute|Paiute]] religious leader who founded a second episode of the [[Ghost Dance]] movement. Wovoka means "cutter"<ref>{{cite book |title= The ghost-dance religion and the Sioux outbreak of 1890|last=Mooney |first=James |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1896 |publisher=G.P.O. |location= |isbn= |page=765 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> or "wood cutter" in the [[Northern Paiute language]].
==Biography== Wovoka was born in the [[Smith Valley]] area southeast of [[Carson City, Nevada]], around 1856. Quoitze Ow was his birth name.<ref>Hittman,"Wovoka And The Ghost Dance:Expanded Edition" (Lincoln, Nebraska:University of Nebraska:Press 1997) 47</ref> Wovoka's father was Numu-tibo'o (sometimes called Tavibo), who for several decades was incorrectly believed to be [[Wodziwob]], a religious leader who had founded the Ghost Dance of 1870.<ref>Du Bois, Cora "The 1870 Ghost Dance" ''Anthropological Records'' Vol. 3, No. 1 (1939) (Berkeley, California; University of California Press) 3-4</ref> From the age of eight until almost thirty Wovoka often worked for David Wilson, a [[rancher]] in the [[Yerington, Nevada]] area, and his wife Abigail, who gave him the name Jack Wilson when dealing with European Americans.<ref>Hittman, Michael ''Wovoka And The Ghost Dance: Expanded Edition'' (Lincoln, Nebraska: University of Nebraska Press 1997) 27-28</ref> David Wilson was a devout [[Christian]], and Wovoka learned [[Christian theology]] and [[Bible stories]] while living with him.<ref>Hittman, ''Wovoka'' 55-56</ref>
One of his chief sources of authority among Paiutes was his alleged ability to control the weather. He was said to have caused a block of ice to fall out of the sky on a summer day, to be able to end drought with rain or snow, to light his pipe with the sun, and to form icicles in his hands.<ref>{{cite book |title= Wovoka and the ghost dance|last=Hittman |first=Michael |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1990 |publisher=University of Nebraska Press |location= |isbn=978-0-8032-7308-5|page=69}}</ref>
Wovoka claimed to have had a [[prophet]]ic vision during the [[solar eclipse of January 1, 1889]]. Wovoka's vision entailed the [[resurrection]] of the Paiute dead, and the removal of whites and their works from [[North America]]. Wovoka taught that in order to bring this vision to pass, the Native Americans must live righteously and perform a traditional round dance, known as the [[Ghost Dance]].
Anthropologists, historians, and theologians alike provide conflicting accounts on when and how Wovoka had his vision. One scholar of religions, Tom Thatcher, cites James Mooney's Smithsonian-sponsored anthropological report to claim that Wovoka received his first vision while chopping wood for David Wilson in 1887.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Thatcher|first=Tom|date=Autumn 1998|title=Empty Metaphors and Apocalyptic Rhetoric|jstor=1466133|journal=Journal of the American Academy of Religion|volume=66|pages=549–570}}</ref> Conversely, historian Paul Bailey utilized Mooney's work along interviews with Wovoka's contemporaries and interpreters to assert that he received the vision after entering a two-day trance, awaking in tears.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Wovoka: The Indian Messiah|last=Bailey|first=Paul|publisher=Westernlore Press|year=1957|isbn=9781258823382|location=Los Angeles|pages=79–83}}</ref> Regardless, shortly after receiving the vision and its message, it moved quickly beyond his local Paiute community by word of mouth to Native American tribes further east, notably the [[Lakota people|Lakota]].
The Ghost Dance movement is known for being practiced by the victims of the [[Wounded Knee Massacre]]. Before the Ghost dance reached Native Americans on South Dakota plains reservations, interest in the movement came from U.S. [[Bureau of Indian Affairs|Indian Office]], [[United States Department of War|U.S. War Department,]] and multiple Native American tribal delegations. Many tribes would arrive in Mason to listen to Wovoka intently, but language barriers existed. Visiting tribes came from different cultures, geographies, and linguistic traditions. Few delegation members could speak Wovoka's mother tongue of Paiute. This led to tribes adopting a militant form of Wovoka's teachings that emphasized an impending battle leading to the creation of the [[Ghost shirt|Ghost Shirts]] worn by Sioux and Lakota at the subsequent massacre.<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=McCann Jr.|first=Frank D.|year=1966|title=The Ghost Dance, Last hope of Western Tribes, Unleashed the Final Tragedy|jstor=4517018|journal=Montana: The Magazine of Western History|volume=16|pages=25–34}}</ref> Other Native American Leaders, such as [[Miniconjou]], [[Arnold Short Bull|Short Bull]] and [[Kicking Bear]] allegedly adopted violent interpretations that emphasized the possible elimination of whites. However, Wovoka never left his home in Nevada to become an active participant in the dance's dissemination in the U.S. interior.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Wovoka: The Indian Messiah|last=Bailey|first=Paul|publisher=Westernlore Press|year=1957|isbn=9781258823382|location=Los Angeles|pages=171}}</ref>
Indian Agents, soldiers, and other federal officials were predisposed towards a militaristic posture and outright violence upon encountering the movement.
==Post-Wounded Knee Life and Death== Wovoka was disheartened by how events unfolded at the massacre. He still remained a prominent Native American leader until his death.<ref name=":22"/> Sometime between 1894-1896, he was reported to have been a sideshow attraction at a San Francisco Midwinter Fair Carnival. In 1917, an agent for the Nevada Agency named L.A. Dorrington tracked down Wovoka to report on his whereabouts to Washington. Curious to see if the former Native American messiah had any ties to Native American [[Peyotism]], Dorrington found that Wovoka was instead living a humble life in Mason. He abstained from the practice, worked as an occasional medicine man, and traveled to events on reservations across the United States.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Stewart|first=Omer C.|year=1977|title=Contemporary Document on Wovoka (Jack Wilson_ Prophet of the Ghost Dance in 1890|jstor=481696|journal=Ethnohistory|volume=24|pages=219–222}}</ref>
Wovoka died in Yerington on September 20, 1932, and is interred in the Paiute Cemetery in the town of [[Schurz, Nevada]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legendsofamerica.com/na-wovoka.html |title= Wovoka - Paiute Medicine Man & the Ghost Dance|author= |date= |work= |publisher=Legends of America |accessdate=2010-04-15}}</ref>
==In popular culture== Native American band [[Redbone (band)|Redbone]] named their 1973 album [[Wovoka (album)|''Wovoka'']], and the title song, after the prophet.
==See also== * [[Smohalla]] * [[John Slocum]] * [[Handsome Lake]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Michael Hittman, ''Wovoka and the Ghost Dance'', Bison Books 1998, {{ISBN|0-8032-7308-8}} *John Norman, ''Ghost Dance'', Daw Books 1970, (a fictional account) {{ISBN|0-87997-501-6}}
==External links== *[http://www.ghostdance.us Ghostdance.us Wovoka Information] *{{Find a Grave|8160629}} *[https://www.pbs.org/weta/thewest/resources/archives/eight/gdmessg.htm ''The Messiah Letter'' by Wovoka, translated by James Mooney] *{{YouTube|cI0Jfdkq4z8|Paiute Native American shaman Wovoka and the Ghost Dance}}

'''Wowaus''', also known as James Printer (c.1650-1709), was an early [[Nipmuc]] writer who helped create the first Indian Bibles in the [[Massachusett language]] (an [[Algonquian languages|Algonquin language]]), which were used by English colonists in the cultural assimilation of Native Americans.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Dawnland Voices: An Anthology of Indigenous Writer from New England|last=Senier|first=Siobhan|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|year=2014|isbn=9780803246867|pages=374}}</ref>
Wowaus was the son of William Sudbury, a Christian Indian leader<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.peabody.harvard.edu/node/479|title=Literacy and the Printing Press|last=|first=|date=|website=Peabody museum of Archeology and Ethnology at Harvard University|publisher=Peabody Museum of Archeology and Ethnology at Harvard University|access-date=24 April 2016}}</ref> from Hassanemesit (today Grafton, Massachusetts). Wowaus became fluent in English as a student at an Indian charity school. He attended Harvard's [[Indian College]] and worked as an apprentice at [[Samuel Green (printer)|Samuel Green]]'s printing press, "The Cambridge Press",<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://americanantiquarian.org/EnglishtoAlgonquian/cambridgepress|title=Cambridge Press|last=|first=|date=|website=From English to Algonquin: Early New England Translations|publisher=americanantiquarian.org|access-date=24 April 2016}}</ref> beginning in 1659. There, he became known by the English name, James Printer. In addition to the Indian Bible, Wowaus assisted Samuel Green in printing many of the Algonquian-language texts that were in circulation throughout the American colonies from 1658 to 1710.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://americanantiquarian.org/EnglishtoAlgonquian/jamesprinter|title=Wowaus, or James Printer (d. 1717)|last=|first=|date=|website=From English to Algonquin: Early American Translations|publisher=americanantiquarian.org|access-date=24 April 2016}}</ref>
In his late life, Wowaus was a teacher in Hassanemesit. His son, Ami, signed the deed that sold the last of the Hassanamesit tribal lands to the in 1727.<ref name="daniels">{{cite book|last1=Daniels|first1=George F.|title=History of the Town of Oxford, Massachusetts: With Genealogies and Notes on Persons and Estates. Oxford: Pub. by the author with the cooperation of the town, 1892.|date=1892|publisher=Pub. by the author with the cooperation of the town|location=Oxford|page=756|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qFEhAQAAIAAJ}}</ref>
